Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Creating a Sense of Obligation: Legal Mobilization for Socioeconomic Rights

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Individuals and movements continue to promote social claims through the courts in many countries across the Global South; in ways that challenge our current understanding of the historical role of the judiciary. Around the world, law has become increasingly apparent in social and political life, a change that runs contrary to traditional democratic and legal theory, which envision a limited role for the non-representative judicial branch. Yet, this increase in legal mobilization may, in fact, be deepening democracy by allowing individuals to directly access and make claims upon the state in otherwise unreceptive political environments. To better situate the role of the judiciary in democratic governance, this project investigates legal mobilization around socio-economic rights using a comparative analysis. The research focuses specifically on the issues of housing and healthcare.

The research plan involves an analysis of legal documents, semi-structured interviews, and participant observation. It includes approximately 100 interviews with lawyers and legal academics in three major cities. And, the researcher will engage in 3 months of participant observation with three community-based organizations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project explored the contestation around rights claims to things like healthcare, housing, and education in the contexts of Colombia and South Africa. It investigated a real-world empirical change that runs contrary to traditional democratic and legal theory, both of which envision a limited role for the judicial branch. Increasingly, however, around the world, the judiciary has taken on a more activate role in relation to concerns about social welfare. This shift profoundly affects the way in which citizens interact with democratic states. The Colombian and South African cases exemplify different ways in which the legal promise of social incorporation influences both citizen claims-making and access to social goods.

Some scholars have argued that the involvement of courts in issues related to social rights inhibit democratic practice, ultimately cracking its foundations through the privileging and empowering of non-representative judicial actors, while others suggest that this type of action allows for democratic progress, even in the face of institutions built upon unequal power relations or other exclusionary practices. The scope and depth of this kind of claims-making in both Colombia and South Africa suggest that elected representatives have not been willing or able to heed the demands of their constituents much of the time. In these cases, social rights claims-making through the courts may, in fact, be deepening democracy by allowing individuals to directly access and make claims to much needed goods, which otherwise would be inaccessible. 

Departing from prior studies, the project takes a holistic view of the process of legal claims-making, investigating the social construction of legal grievances (or when problems are understood to be claimable through the legal system), legal opportunity (or when claims actually advance through the legal system), and judicial receptivity (or when judges accept the claims that come before them) together. In total, the project involved 178 interviews with legal elites, nearly 100 interviews with rights claimants, two original surveys, and a quantitative analysis of social rights court cases in each country. The project directly contributes to scholarship on law and society, contentious politics, and comparative politics, while also deepening our knowledge about important societal outcomes, including representation, accountability, and the provision of social welfare, paying special attention to the points at which human agency can impact structural and institutional conditions.

Financial support from the National Science Foundation allowed for nine months of fieldwork in South Africa, split between Johannesburg, Durban, and Cape Town. This fieldwork was comprised of interviews with 82 lawyers, judges, and activists, an original 551-person survey, and the creation of a database of legal cases related to health, housing, education, water, and social security. This data collection effort has allowed the researcher to make presentations and academic conferences in the fields of political science and law and society and to begin preparing article- and book-length manuscripts for publication.
